title: The Ian Burton Adventure
content:
Heh, I'm back, and this time with a more laid back project that I'm working on in my spare time. It's a Keen 1 hack, starring none other than myself. I've not got a plot firmly in place yet, but I'm thinking it'll be something to do with me, space pirates and maybe even Commander Keen. We'll see. Anyhow, I've not much done yet, the walking sprites and this neat little "One Moment" screen replacement.

[img]http://www.zxdware.net/tiba1.gif[/img]

I've got plenty else to do, so don't expect this to be done in an instant, if anyone even is interested in this premise. All I know is that it ought to be neato when (and if) it's done.

title: Re: re: Keen-related
content:
Let me guess... Dig in? Naah.

Space Pirates are often equipped with old planes, which they souped up to their own taste. Their chosen craft should be old (because it is cheaper), modifiable (if it's old...), equipped with a lot of shields (we are talking about individuals, not a fleet!), a reserved engine (or hyperdrive if you like) for escaping patrols and weaponry able to disable, and if they want to, destroy ships. Their main targets are transports and unarmed convoys, because these are easy to disable and carry a lot of stuff beyond imagination. If they steal a personal craft (I think your main character has a fighter-like vehicle, not a huge cruiser, right?), that can be of 3 reasons:
1: the craft has something they want to use in their own ships
2: they have had personal problems with the owner of the craft
3: the craft itself is worth a lot (which in case of a personal transport I doubt) and can be sold for a lot of cash.

Heh heh, I was actually considering pasting my logo over the PC Maniac Mansion opening sequence, where the mansion's in the distance, and there are hills, stars and the moon. Since it seemed to be 16 color, it worked out quite well, heh heh. But my house looks more different than the mansion than I wanted, and I kinda felt cheap ripping that directly off for this. Even though I'm ripping so many other things off. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

Still, I think I may add some stars and put the burning ship back in. As for the appearance of the ship, it's gonna be pretty simple. Saucer shaped, a lot like the UFOs you encounter in EarthBound. Only... you know, big enough for people to be in.

I believe someone suggested the main character had a ship of some sort? This is not the case. The character is just a regular teenage kid who lives in the middle of nowhere, who falls victim to invading space pirates.

As for what he'll be doing, well. When he finds out that pirates from space are not only invading the countryside, but have stolen his four most precious posessions (Computer, TV, two other yet to be determined objects) he grabs himself a shotgun and sets out to get his stuff back. And, well, to hopefully chase the space pirates off.

Level design, well, I'll probably need a hand for tiles and mapping, though I can do some sketches of level ideas if anyone would care to help me. I'm already starting to bubble and stew ideas in my head over this. I just hope there are enough tiles to accomodate a rural setting AND an alien technological setting. ><

So yeah, that's about all for now.

title: Re: new title!
content:
Anti-aliasing - blurring edges to give the appearance of diagonal lines being "smooth"; often used in 3D games so that the models don't look rough.

"Smoothing" is probably a more appropriate word here.
If Keen eats all that sugar, why doesn't he get a coronary?

title: Re: new title!
content:
Actually anti-aliasing doesn't make models look less rough.
With "models" I'm talking about the 3D meshes.
The end result, the characters or weapons for instance, will generally look more refined because of AA thoughl of course.

FSAA (Full Screen Anti Aliasing) will basically treat the final image rendered, so basically your 1024 x 768 (or whatever resolution the game plays at), as a texture, and put some AA on that.
This will help the models stand out from the background a bit less, making things look more real.
You can do this with 2D games too.
Run your Keen through DOSbox and select the appropiate filter.

There are some video cards that add extra polygons to models resulting in a smoother look, but gun barrels which are supposed to be slender tubes, will also often look bloated like balloons, so it's not really better than playing without the option.

In a Keen mod the best you can do is put some grey in between black and white, and/or dither the colours, but you are severly limited compared to more recent games.Retodon8

title: Fixes
content:
Well, if you click the link above, I've fixed the Psychobilly's walk and the hair cutoff. I understand the Psychobilly thing perfectly; I myself even thought it looked strange, comparing it to the walk of Bagman, from the arcade game of the same name. Seriously, if you ever happen to play it, you'll notice right away what I mean.

As for the hair cutoff, that was a strange thing. I first made it 8 bigger, but found that if I landed a jump, I continually fell THROUGH THE FLOOR. So I simply lifted the legs more. All in all, the jump is almost perfect now. There is, however, still one problem I need to work on.

THE JUMPING JITTERS, as I've dubbed them, ARE A TOUGH PROBLEM TO FIX. It seems that if I move him much more towards the left, the front of his hair will end up getting cut off, and it'll look terrible. I'm gonna fiddle with this a little more, but if I can't get it, I may release the sprites and see if somebody more experienced can't get a handle on the situation.

Anyways, I'm thinking about level design and the like, I may start up with some tile stuff soon. I think I'm going to turn the clam plant into a snapping bear trap. As for enemies, the Vorticon will become a Space Pirate, the Sentry Robot a Space Pirate with a Jello Pistol, but as for the rest, I'm open for suggestions.

Oh, and if anyone's interested, I've already started planning a sequel, curse my creativity. It'll only ever exist if I get enough C++ programming knowledge to create my own engine, though.

EDIT: I fixed the jumping jitters as well as I could. I can't notice it anymore.

Also, I'm curious as to why nobody has commented on the fact that when you shoot the Psychobilly, his HEAD EXPLODES.

title: Re: huh?
content:
The Patchwork Mod thread has a link to [url=http://andy.durdin.net/keen/modding/viewtopic.php?t=381]andy.durdin.net/keen/modd....php?t=381[/url] where Adurdin explains his steps quite detailed.

You first need to disassemble the game, which basically gives you a text file with the source code.
(This is not the source code the programmers wrote exactly, because useful things like comments (that don't actually do anything) are stripped from this version, making it much harder to understand what happens.)

In assembly you use certain addresses to store data.
For instance Adurdin found the word "London" stored in there somewhere.
Also there are certain commands that calculate things, and can manipulate the data as well.
There are commands that add 1 to the number in a specified address for instance, meaning a 5 would become a 6.
A command could also substract 1, or add the numbers from 2 addresses together.

If you look at the source, you see the mnemonic (pretty much the same thing as "abbreviation") "INC", which (if I remember correctly) increases something by 1 like I mentioned above.
A computer chip doesn't understand words, but compilers translate things like INC to a specific piece of code it does understand.
Apparently the decompiler Adurdin uses, shows the more understandable (to humans at least) mnemonics as well.

You should get a book on the subject to get a good description, but my point is all those commands, all those 2, 3, or 4 letter mnemonics are really puny, they can barely do anything.
The trick with programming is to combine all those tiny things to accomplish something bigger.

The thing Adurdin is doing, is trying to figure out which set of tiny things are doing certain bigger things.
Once he figures that out, he can patch those commands or values; change them into something different.
Through that he changes what the game does.

I'm not sure this description helps, especially since it's been ages since I programmed in Assembly Language, and I never was any good, but read the other thread I linked to and maybe you'll get the general idea.
It just is difficult to work with Assembly if you ask me.Retodon8

title: Layer.
content:
I've found the easiest way to create a walking animation is to work in layers. Draw the frames for one leg, then duplicate them and line them up in a different order complementary to the other, then do the same for the arms. Attach the final result, along with a head, to the torso and you're pretty much set, give or take a bit of tweaking to make the overall result look nicer.

I'll post an example sometime. At the moment it's all part of a TGF game and I don't feel like converting the sprites to GIF. Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

title: Progress Report & Further Ideas
content:
Well, things are going fairly well. The yorp and garg replacements (Mimrock and Psychobilly respectively, if you forgot) have long been finished, and the Space Pirate needs only death frames. I'm going to look into the possibility of editing Ian's walking frames a little before moving on to finally replace the jumping frames, and then the pogo stick.

Further ideas have come to me in the process of my continued work. I will probably be replacing the Sentry Robots with Space Krakens* (as depicted in VBIAFHC #3), who will bob along on tentacled limbs and fire deadly rays from their eyes. The freeze cannons will be either a variant of the current space pirates in some sort of blast armor, or Square Strongbody (VBIAFHC #5) carrying a stasis ray cannon. Stasis rays are going to be how I explain the fact that there are free floating objects outside--the pirates left some things floating around in stasis fields while rampaging through the countryside.

I'll do a sprite for either one (armored space pirate and Strongbody) and see which one you guys like better.

EDIT: Here's the space pirate stasis cannon trooper, or whatever I end up calling it.

[img]http://www.zxdware.net/spacepirate_stasis.png[/img]

Unless somebody else really wants to see a Strongbody to compare with, I'm probably going with this.

*EDIT #2: Space Kraken.

[img]http://www.zxdware.net/spacekraken.gif[/img]

I'm having problems, though. Maybe it's because I've yet to replace all the sprites of the Sentry Robot with those sized for the Space Kraken. But if it isn't, could somebody make me a quick patch that draws the Sentry Robot enemy eight pixels higher? Otherwise, it gets caught in the ground.

EDIT #3: I replaced all the frames. Now it actually seems to be stuck FURTHER in the ground. A screenshot, if that would help:

[img]http://www.zxdware.net/theproblemwithspacekrakens.png[/img]

As for level design, I'm thinking it'll be mainly forested areas for the outside levels. title: Re: The Ian Burton Adventure

I sounds like you're thoroughly psyching yourself out there. Just make sure the height and width are multiples of 8. That's all there is to it, and if they're all right then it's something else.

title: edits of editted editing edits who are also editing
content:
The width of the sprite itself as it appears in-game must be a multiple of 8, which means that the sprite bitmap file that you have in your folder must have a width that is a multiple of 24, because of the 3-part nature of their construction.

The "color" part of the sprite must be a multiple of 8, the "masking" part of the sprite must be a multiple of 8, and the "collision" part of the sprite must be a multiple of 8...

For example, if you're using MSPaint, it Ctrl+E to bring up the image properties--the width should be either 24, 48, 72, or 96. Anything else is likely to be too large to be usable--you should only have one or two that are 96, anyway. The height shouldn't matter, but don't get rediculous.

Hope that helps...

content: Gmail is easily fooled. Just change the file extension to something that isn't .zip or .exe, and voila.

Ick. Those weren't there before... hm...

Try recompressing those? X_X

I know very little (i.e. nothing) about the compression routines used in the game, so I don't know what to say in terms of that...
